translated: The Elders’ Birth Stories🔽. The Chapter with Bandhujīvaka
It was covered with lotuses and water lilies,
and was surrounded by white water lilies.
I was a bird named Kukuttha
I was virtuous, endowed with wisdom,
skilled in what is meritorious and unmeritorious.
Padumuttara, the knower of the world,
was wandering about not far from the lake;
the Great Sage was wandering about.
I offered it to the Great Seer;
The Great Sage, knowing my intention,
I was inspired by the white-robed one;
I did not go to a bad destination.
These eight were rulers of the people,
… the Buddha’s instruction has been accomplished.”

original: Itthaṁ sudaṁ āyasmā kumudadāyako thero imā gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.
analyzed: ittham sudam āyasmā kumudadāyakaḥ theraḥ imāḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsittha ati
translated: Thus have I heard. This was said by the Elder Kumudadāyaka.
The Story of the Elder Kumudadāyaka is the tenth.
